VII. Cost Approach

The Cost Approach is one of the three methods used to estimate the value of the subject property. This approach is based on the principle that the value of a property is equal to the cost to replace or reproduce the improvements, less depreciation.

A. Estimation of the Cost to Replace or Reproduce the Improvements
The appraiser has estimated the cost to replace or reproduce the improvements on the subject property to be $2,500,000. This estimate is based on the current cost of labor and materials in the Oakland market.

B. Deductions for Depreciation
The appraiser has estimated the depreciation of the improvements to be $1,200,000. This depreciation is based on the appraiser's analysis of the age, condition, and remaining useful life of the subject property's improvements.

C. Calculation of the Property Value using the Cost Approach
The value indicated by the Cost Approach does not support the appraiser's final opinion of market value for the subject property. This is because the value indicated by the Cost Approach is significantly lower than the values indicated by the Income and Sales Comparison Approaches.

In this case, the appraiser gave more weight to the indications of value derived from the Income and Sales Comparison Approaches in determining the final opinion of market value for the subject property for several reasons. First, the Income Approach is well-suited for properties that generate income, such as commercial real estate. The subject property is a gas station that generates significant annual revenue, making the Income Approach an appropriate method for estimating its value.

Second, the Sales Comparison Approach is a widely accepted method for estimating the value of properties that are similar to the subject property and have recently sold. In this case, the appraiser identified several comparable properties that have recently sold and made adjustments to their sale prices based on differences with the subject property to estimate its value.

While the Cost Approach provides useful insights into the subject property's value and condition, it may not reflect the actual market conditions or demand for the property, and may not account for any unique features or characteristics that would affect its market value. For example, the Cost Approach does not consider any economic or functional obsolescence that may affect the value of the subject property. Given these factors, the appraiser chose to give more weight to the Income and Sales Comparison Approaches in determining the final opinion of market value for the subject property.
